generif.text: Observational study of genotype prevalence. (HuGE Navigator)
ARD1-mediated acetylation regulates and destabilizes HIF-1 alpha by directly binding to it.

Human Naa15 (NATH) and Naa10 (ARD1) form a stable NatA complex which associates with ribosomes and performs co-translational N-terminal acetylation; Naa15 (NATH) and Naa10 (ARD1) are cleaved during apoptosis resulting in decreased acetyltransferase activity
description of the human homologue of Nat1p, NATH (NAT human), as the binding partner of the hARD1 (human ARD1) protein
hARD1 complexes with NATH in a ribosomal associated protein-N-acetyltransferase complex.
Amino-terminal acetyltransferase ARD1 (hARD1) interacts with a novel motif, 658-HGVVEVD-664, in the cytoplasmic domain of beta-amyloid precursor protein.
ARD1 is involved in cell proliferation and in regulating a series of cellular metabolic pathways that are regulated during hypoxia response.
Data demonstrate that ARD1 has limited, if any, impact on the HIF-1alpha signaling pathway.
levels of endogenous NATH and hARD1 proteins in thyroid papillary carcinoma patients; results suggest that NATH positively affects the level of hARD1 protein both in vivo and in cell cultures
ARD1 specifically binds HIF-1 alpha, suggesting a putative, still unclear, connection between these proteins.
A human ARD1 variant ortholog (235) has weak effects on hypoxia inducible factor (HIF)-1 alpha and VEGF mRNA stability compared to mouse ARD1 ortholog 225.
Essential role in cell survival through protein N-alpha-acetylation.

Structural characterization of native hARD1 using size exclusion chromatography, circular dichroism, & fluorescence spectroscopy shows the protein consists of compact globular region comprising 2 thirds of the protein & a flexible unstructured C terminus.
These results indicate that ARD1(235) and ARD1(225) isoforms may have different activities and function in different subcellular compartments of mammalian cells.
HIF-1alpha was found to inactivate the Wnt signaling by binding to hARD1 or beta-catenin, which may contribute to the hypoxia-induced growth arrest of tumor cells.
ARD1A is implicated in cellular proliferation and carcinogenesis.
This review focuses on the enzymatic and biological activities of human ARD1, the reduction of which negatively affects cell growth and may be a potential cancer drug target.
accumulation of hARD1 protein may be related to carcinogenesis of various types of cancer.
Observational study of gene-disease association. (HuGE Navigator)
ARD1 is indeed a bona fide substrate of IKKbeta.
hARD1 is a bona fide regulator of MLCK, and hARD1 plays a crucial role in the balance between tumor cell migration and stasis
Results suggest that hARD1 might play an important role in breast cancer carcinogenesis.
Observational study of gene-disease association. (HuGE Navigator)
ARD1 functions as an inhibitor of the mTOR pathway and that dysregulation of the ARD1-TSC2-mTOR axis may contribute to cancer development
Data indicate that the physical interaction between HYPK and NatA Naa10/15 seems to be of functional importance both for huntingtin aggregation and for N-terminal acetylation.
Results show that hARD1 autoacetylation is critical for its activation and its ability to stimulate cancer cell proliferation and tumorigenesis.
interaction between hNaa10p and DNMT1 was required for E-cadherin silencing through promoter CpG methylation, and E-cadherin repression contributed to the oncogenic effects of hNaa10p.
Observational study of gene-disease association, gene-environment interaction, and pharmacogenomic / toxicogenomic. (HuGE Navigator)
These results indicate that ARD1A is a novel tumor-associated antigen and a potential prognostic factor for colon cancer.
suggest that Naa10p functions as a tumor metastasis suppressor by disrupting the migratory complex, PIX-GIT- Paxillin, in cancer cells
N(alpha)-acetyltransferase 10 may function as a post-translational actin N(alpha)-acetyltransferase.
A reduction in acetylation by hNaa10p causes lethal X-linked disorder of infancy.
Arrest-defective protein 1 homolog A (ARD1) in combination with SNCG/Hiwi/PRL-3 may lead to a poor outcome in patients with or without lymph node metastatic colon cancer.
ARD1 functions as a unique AR regulator in prostate cancer cells.
study revealed a novel mechanism controlling MCL1 expression, in which Naa10p and RelA/p65 synergistically interact with MCL1 promoter region and promote MCL1 transcription

These data indicate that the interaction between ARD1 and RIP1 plays an important role in the DNA damage-induced NF-kappaB activation, and that the acetyltransferase activity of ARD1 and its localization in to the nucleus are involved in such stress response.
Protein N-terminal acetyltransferases (NATs), including Naa10, act as N-terminal propionyltransferases.
The expression level of NAA10 is inversely correlated with that of MMP-9 in breast cancer samples.
Development of the first specific NAT-inhibitors, including inhibitors targeting Naa10.
Naa10p suppresses 28S proteasome activity through interaction with PA28beta.

Study describes a Saccharomyces cerevisiae model developed by introducing the human wild-type (wt) or mutant NatA complex into yeast lacking NatA (NatA-Delta). The wt human NatA complex phenotypically complemented the NatA-Delta strain, whereas only a partial rescue was observed for the Ogden mutant NatA complex suggesting that hNaa10 S37P is only partially functional in vivo.
The study concludes that the NAA10 mutation is the cause of Lenz microphthalmia syndrome in a family, likely through the dysregulation of the retinoic acid signalling pathway.
Naa10p inhibits the metastasis of breast cancer cells by targeting STAT5a.
De novo missense mutations in the NAA10 gene cause severe non-syndromic developmental delay in males and females
results show that hARD1 nuclear translocation mediated by NLS is required for cell cycle progression, thereby contributing to proper cell proliferation.
Autoacetylation of ARD1 variants differentially regulates angiogenesis and cell proliferation in an isoform-specific manner.
ARD1 has a crucial role in the cellular response to oxidative stress as a bona fide regulator of MSRA.
human ARD1 variants have different effects on cell proliferation, which may result from distinct subcellular localizations and autoacetylation activities.
Combined high expression of Naa10p, SNCG and PRL-3 are associated with lymph node metastasis in breast cancer.
Naa10 structure and function. [Review]
The clinical spectrum of NAA10.
The results observed an inverse correlation between the expression of NAA10 and that of miR-342-5p and miR-608 .
our study illustrated that the expression of Naa10p had a potential value for predicting the progression of OSCC and prognosis of OSCC patients.
there is no difference in lysine acetylation of substrate proteins with or without Naa10, suggesting that the substrates may be acetylated chemically rather than enzymatically.

Study reports on a total of 12 affected females with four different de novo missense mutations in NAA10 and one inherited mutation in a familial case due to germline mosaicism, thus further expanding themutational and clinical spectrum associated with NAA10 related N-terminal-acetyltransferase deficiency.
Expression of ARD1 increases levels of androgen receptor acetylation and androgen receptor-HSP90 dissociation in a dose dependent manner.
ARD1-mediated Hsp70 acetylation is a regulatory mechanism that temporally balances protein refolding/degradation in response to stress
Negative regulation of Naa10 towards NTN1 and its receptor UNC5B were also detected upon treatment of all-trans retinoid acid, which was often used to induce morphological differentiation.
In combination with acetylation assays, the HypK N-terminal region is identified as a negative regulator of the NatA acetylation activity

A novel de novo NAA10 c.332 T>G p.(Val111Gly) missense variant was detected in a girl with mild/moderate non-syndromic intellectual disability. NAA10 V111G displayed reduced monomeric NAT activity and stability, but intact NatA-mediated NAT activity.

A novel NAA10 mutation was identified in three cases of developmental delay, intellectual disability, and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Pathogenic NAA10 variant impaired acetyltransferase activity and stability.
Results show that NAA10 active site is regulated by HYPK inhibiting the activity of N-terminal acetyltransferases A.

Higher NAA10 transcripts were observed in metastatic osteosarcoma tissues and correlated with worse prognosis. Its knockdown and overexpression in osteosarcoma cells respectively led to decreased and increased cell migratory/invasive abilities. Naa10p was directly associated with MMP-2 protein through its acetyltransferase domain maintaining MMP-2 protein stability.
Upstream IKKbeta can further promote the occurrence of breast cancer by mediating the function of ARD1.
Since the FIH-1 dependent hydroxylation of NAA10 occurs oxygen-dependently, NAA10 acetylates HIF-1alpha under normoxia but does not under hypoxia.
Data show that N-alpha-acetyltransferase 10 (NAA10) as a factor in the transcriptional machinery regulating pregnaneXreceptor (PXR) transcription.
We reviewed recognised variants in PAS associated with Mendelian disorders and identified only 23 others, indicating that NAA10 harbours more than 10% of all known PAS variants.

higher expression level of Naa10 and lower expression level of Pirh2 in oral squamous cell carcinoma tissues than adjacent normal tissues; expression of Naa10p is negatively correlated with that of Pirh2
Structure and mechanism of acetylation by the N-terminal dual enzyme NatA/Naa50 complex has been reported.
Data suggest a model where reduced N(alpha)-acetyltransferase 10 N(alpha)-acetyltransferase 10, NatA catalytic subunit (NAA10) activity cause the phenotypes observed in the two patients.
our study confirmed that miR-342/Naa10p plays key roles in AML progression

The ARD1-mediated protein acetylation plays an important role in modulating several cellular events that are important for cancer development, such as cell cycle progression, cell death, and migration.
Stabilization of ADAM9 by N-alpha-acetyltransferase 10 protein contributes to promoting progression of androgen-independent prostate cancer.
NAA10 p.(N101K) disrupts N-terminal acetyltransferase complex NatA and is associated with developmental delay and hemihypertrophy.
Variants in NAA15 cause pediatric hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
NAA10 p.(D10G) and NAA10 p.(L11R) Variants Hamper Formation of the NatA N-Terminal Acetyltransferase Complex.
NAA10 promotes proliferation of renal cell carcinoma by upregulating UPK1B.
NAA10 variant in 38-week-gestation male patient: a case study.
Naa10p and IKKalpha interaction regulates EMT in oral squamous cell carcinoma via TGF-beta1/Smad pathway.
Confirmation of Ogden syndrome as an X-linked recessive fatal disorder due to a recurrent NAA10 variant and review of the literature.
Hydroxylation of the Acetyltransferase NAA10 Trp38 Is Not an Enzyme-Switch in Human Cells.
Biochemical analysis of novel NAA10 variants suggests distinct pathogenic mechanisms involving impaired protein N-terminal acetylation.
N-alpha-Acetyltransferase 10 inhibits invasion and metastasis of oral squamous cell carcinoma via regulating Pirh2-p53 signalling pathway.
Naa10p promotes cell invasiveness of esophageal cancer by coordinating the c-Myc and PAI1 regulatory axis.
ARD1 stabilizes NRF2 through direct interaction and promotes colon cancer progression.
Phenotypic variability and gastrointestinal manifestations/interventions for growth in NAA10-related neurodevelopmental syndrome.
Expanding the phenotypic spectrum of NAA10-related neurodevelopmental syndrome and NAA15-related neurodevelopmental syndrome.
NAA10 overexpression dictates distinct epigenetic, genetic, and clinicopathological characteristics in adult gliomas.
Studying Long QT Syndrome Caused by NAA10 Genetic Variants Using Patient-Derived Induced Pluripotent Stem Cells.
NAA10 gene expression is associated with mesenchymal transition, dedifferentiation, and progression of clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

BP.term: negative regulation of maintenance of mitotic sister chromatid cohesion, centromeric

name: N-alpha-acetyltransferase 10, NatA catalytic subunit
other_names: N-terminal acetyltransferase complex ARD1 subunit homolog A
microphthalmia or anophthalmia and associated anomalies

pid.name: Hypoxic and oxygen homeostasis regulation of HIF-1-alpha

summary: N-alpha-acetylation is among the most common post-translational protein modifications in eukaryotic cells. This process involves the transfer of an acetyl group from acetyl-coenzyme A to the alpha-amino group on a nascent polypeptide and is essential for normal cell function. This gene encodes an N-terminal acetyltransferase that functions as the catalytic subunit of the major amino-terminal acetyltransferase A complex. Mutations in this gene are the cause of Ogden syndrome. Alternate splicing results in multiple transcript variants. [provided by RefSeq, Jan 2012].
